explanation:
To prove the absence (or presence) of direct or indirect self-calls involving send_bad_request we must inspect all functions it directly calls and any functions those may call that could lead back to send_bad_request (or to its callers). Explanations:

- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static: direct callee of send_bad_request; any recursion path could originate here.
- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls: callee of MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static; include to follow transitive calls.
- MHD_queue_response: direct callee of send_bad_request; it is complex and may call into connection/response management code that could cycle back.
- MHD_DLOG: callee of MHD_queue_response; include to ensure it does not call back into higher-level request handlers.
- is_reply_body_needed: callee of MHD_queue_response; include to rule out callbacks into request-handling functions.
- MHD_increment_response_rc: callee of MHD_queue_response; include to rule out indirect recursion via reference-counting callbacks.
- MHD_connection_handle_idle: callee of MHD_queue_response; connection-management functions can sometimes invoke request callbacks, so include.
- MHD_update_last_activity_: callee of MHD_queue_response; include to rule out callbacks.
- MHD_destroy_response: direct callee of send_bad_request; include to verify it does not call into request handlers (or send_bad_request).
- ahc_cb: listed caller of send_bad_request; a recursion cycle could go through this request callback, so its body must be inspected.
- send_chat_page & send_upgrade_required: callees of ahc_cb and peers of send_bad_request; include because ahc_cb may call them and they may call back into the request handling chain.
- MHD_create_response_for_upgrade & MHD_add_response_header: other ahc_cb callees that manipulate responses/headers and could contain callbacks into higher-level handlers.

By examining these symbols (their calls and callees) the analyst can determine whether any transitive call sequence from send_bad_request leads back to itself (directly or indirectly) and thus whether the MISRA recursion rule is violated.
